title: Drug firms accused of conspiring to hike prices on life-saving NHS medicine
text:
Three drugs firms have been accused of rigging the supply of a life-saving medicine used by thousands of patients on the NHS to boost their profits.

South African pharma giant Aspen bribed two rivals so that it could maintain its monopoly over the supply of fludrocortisone acetate tablets to the NHS, the Competition and Markets Authority said in a provisional ruling.

Fludrocortisone is used to treat Addison’s Disease, a condition where the adrenal glands do not produce enough steroid hormones. It affects around 8,400 people in the UK and causes weight loss, weakness and joint and muscle pain.
